⚡ Quick check — 30 seconds

Answer honestly. If 2 or more answers sting, use the tool below.

1Today I am reacting more than choosing?
2Am I seeking approval or truth?
3Am I deciding in haste, under emotion?
4Does this choice bring me closer to Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ or numb me?
If 2+ answers sting → use "How do you feel today?" and choose 🛡 Protection or 🧭 Advice.

ثبات — Thabat

A space to nourish the heart with Qur'an, Sunnah and mental clarity — in daily trials, difficult questions, moments of doubt.

Thabat means firmness, stability — the gift the Prophet ﷺ asked for the believers.

MOMENT TOOL

How do you feel today?

Choose your state and what you need — you will receive tailored guidance.

1 How do you feel right now?
FAITH TOOL

Going through something difficult?

If you feel faith drifting away — or facing a specific trial — choose where you are. No judgment. Just a word for you, guidance from Qur'an and Sunnah, and an honest analysis of how Shayṭān works in that situation.

LETTERS OF THE HEART — رسائل القلب

Help someone understand the pain you have been through

These letters are written to be shared with those who have hurt you — not to accuse, but to make felt, with measured words and Islamic awareness, the weight of what happened. Choose the relationship that concerns you.

Each letter helps the reader understand — through introspection and fear of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — the pain that their words or silence have caused. It is not anger. It is truth spoken with mercy.

🌿 PATH OF RECOGNITION — A JOURNEY FOR THOSE WHO ARE NOT SURE

You don't need faith to begin. You only need honesty.

No debates to win. No pressure to conform.

Just a willingness to look carefully — at your own experience.

1
Have you ever examined your disbelief — or did you mostly inherit it from your environment? ▼
That already shows integrity.
Then you are not here to defend a slogan — you are here to examine reality.
Let's continue carefully.
That is more common than we admit.
Many beliefs — religious or anti-religious — are inherited.
Examining them is a sign of maturity.
That might be the most honest answer.
Indifference often hides postponed questions.
Let's bring them forward gently.

→ Before discussing God, let's begin somewhere more immediate: your own experience.

2
Have you ever felt something bigger than you — and then explained it away? ▼

A sunset that silenced you.
A birth.
A loss.
A moment of stillness.

That moment was real.
Calling it "just chemistry" explains the mechanism, not the meaning.
The experience itself still asks to be understood.
Every experience has chemistry.
But chemistry describes how neurons fire — not whether the experience corresponds to something real.
The question remains open.
That's possible.
Sometimes distraction becomes our atmosphere.
Still, stay with the next question.

→ Let's talk about something harder to dismiss.

3
Is there something in your life that truly matters — not just that you enjoy, but that losing it would feel wrong? ▼

A child.
A parent.
A partner.
Your dignity.

That "I can't explain why" is important.
You are recognizing value as real — not invented.
Where does that kind of value come from?
If value is constructed, it can be deconstructed.
Yet when love is betrayed, it does not feel like preference violated.
It feels like something real was broken.
Then consider this carefully:
Why does love feel binding — not optional?

→ Now we move to something even sharper.

4
When you witnessed deep injustice — did it only register as a fact, or did it hurt? ▼

A child suffering without fault.
Corruption rewarded.
Cruelty unpunished.

You reacted as if something objective had been violated.
Not "I dislike this."
But "This should not be."

Where does that "should" come from?
Empathy may explain why we feel outrage.
But it does not explain why we believe injustice is truly wrong — even when it benefits us.
Notice something profound:
To be angry at God for injustice assumes a moral standard higher than the world.
That standard itself points somewhere.

→ You live as if meaning and justice are real. Let's consider what that implies.

5
If there were Someone behind reality — what would you want to say? ▼

Not whether you believe.
If there were.

Questions are not barriers to faith.
They are often its doorway.
Anger implies expectation.
Pain implies relationship.
Those are not the language of indifference.
Silence can also be honest.
Sometimes the first step is simply listening.
That is one of the rarest answers.
Listening is openness without defensiveness.
"When My servants ask you about Me — indeed I am near. I respond to the call of the caller when he calls upon Me." (2:186)

The Qur'an does not begin with proof.
It begins with nearness.
The Invitation

At this point, something has likely happened:

You recognized meaning.
You recognized value.
You recognized moral reality.
You recognized relational possibility.

You do not need complete certainty.

Only sincerity.

If you believe — even quietly — that there is one ultimate source of reality,
and that Muhammad brought His message,

then entering Islam is simple.

It requires no ceremony.
Only recognition spoken aloud:

أَشْهَدُ أَنْ لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا ٱللَّهُ وَأَشْهَدُ أَنَّ مُحَمَّدًا رَسُولُ ٱللَّهِ

Ashhadu an lā ilāha illa Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ,
wa ashhadu anna Muḥammadan rasūlu Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ.

"I testify that there is no god but Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ,
and I testify that Muhammad is the messenger of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ."

You do not need to know everything.

You do not need to be perfect.

You begin where you are.

If you are not ready — that is alright.

But do one thing tonight:

Say honestly,

"O Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — if You are real, guide me."

And then pay attention.

PATH TO FAITH — طريق الإيمان
I. You Are Still Here

You are still here.

You could have closed this. You did not.

That matters.

This is not a demand for belief. It is a quiet space to consider something you may have postponed.
No pressure. No performance. Just honesty.

II. The Question You Cannot Silence

At some point — maybe late at night, maybe in silence — a question surfaces:

Why am I here?

Not how did life form. Why do I exist?

You can distract yourself. You can achieve things. You can accumulate experiences.
But the question returns.

"I did not create jinn and humans except to worship Me." (51:56)

Worship here means orientation — living in alignment with the One who made you.

What if your restlessness is not emptiness — but a signal?

III. You Were Not an Accident

"Indeed, I will place a vicegerent upon the earth." (2:30)

Before your birth, intention. Before your story, purpose.

The Qur'an presents the human being as entrusted — not random.

This changes everything.
If life is accidental, meaning is fragile. If life is intentional, meaning is discoverable.

IV. The Inner Conflict

You feel tension inside you.
One impulse pulls toward clarity. Another pulls toward distraction.

The Qur'an records a declaration:

"I will come at them from before them and from behind them…" (7:16–17)

Future anxiety. Past regret. Desire beautified. Goodness made to look naive.

This description is unsettling because it feels familiar.

But then:

"Over My servants you have no authority." (7:18)

You are not controlled. You are addressed.
Awareness restores freedom.

V. Signs Placed in Time

Faith is not presented as blind.
The Qur'an anchors itself in history:

The Roman Empire predicted to recover after crushing defeat (30:2–4).
Pharaoh's body preserved as a future sign (10:92).
Abū Lahab condemned while alive, with no reversal (111).
The barefoot shepherds competing in tall buildings (Ḥadīth of Jibrīl).
Islam reaching wherever night and day reach.

These claims exist in time. They can be examined.

You are not asked to suspend reason. You are asked to use it.

VI. Nearness

After arguments, history, and reflection — the tone shifts.

"When My servants ask you about Me — indeed I am near." (2:186)

Near.

Not distant. Not abstract. Near.

No intermediary required. No ritual prerequisite. No prior perfection.
Only sincerity.

VII. The Threshold

You do not need full certainty to begin.
You only need willingness.

Tonight, alone, say:

"O Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — if You are real, guide me to what is true."

Say it once. Honestly.

Then observe.

Faith rarely begins with thunder. It begins with a door opening quietly inside you.
And once opened, it does not fully close again.

PATH TO FAITH — طريق الإيمان

You are still here. That matters.

A quiet space — no pressure, no performance. Seven steps from the question you cannot silence to the threshold of faith.

PRAYER — الصَّلَاة

Why ṣalāh is the heart of everything

Prayer is not a bureaucratic obligation. It is the only direct thread to Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — five times a day. Here you find the meaning of each posture, how Shayṭān works to make you stop, the deepest ḥadīth, and — if you are in difficulty — a direct word about where you are.

إِنَّ ٱلصَّلَوٰةَ تَنۡهَىٰ عَنِ ٱلۡفَحۡشَآءِ وَٱلۡمُنكَرِ

"Prayer forbids obscenity and evil."

Qur'an 29:45 — Sūrat al-ʿAnkabūt

🧵

The thread with Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ

The word ṣalāh comes from the root meaning "connection". It is not a ritual — it is a direct thread. Five times a day the thread tightens. Every prayer left behind is a moment in which it loosens.

🧭

The compass of the heart

Prayer resets the inner compass. Every rakʿa is a return to the centre: to who you are, where you come from, where you are going. Whoever prays regularly never completely loses their bearing.

🛡

The shield against sin

Prayer forbids obscenity and evil. It is not a vague promise: presence before Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ purifies the heart and weakens the impulses that lead to sin. There is an invisible shield.

⚖️

The first reckoning in the ākhirah

"The first thing the servant will be called to account for is prayer." If it is sound, everything else is facilitated. If it is deficient, everything else is at risk. It is not one thing among others — it is the foundation.

🕰 Why five times a day?

صُبْح
Fajr — Dawn: The day begins with Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ. Before the world, before work. Fajr says: my first thought is for You.
ظُهْر
Ẓuhr — Midday: At the peak of the day, in the midst of work — a pause. Realignment at the halfway point.
عَصْر
ʿAṣr — Afternoon: When work slows and tiredness arrives. An entire surah is dedicated to it: time is precious.
مَغْرِب
Maghrib — Sunset: The day ends. Gratitude at sunset is among the most powerful spiritual acts.
عِشَاء
ʿIshāʾ — Night: Before sleep, one last contact. The day closes with Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, as it began. Sleep becomes tawakkul.
وَأَقِمِ ٱلصَّلَوٰةَ لِذِكۡرِي

"Establish prayer for My remembrance."

Qur'an 20:14 — Sūrat Ṭā-Hā

🔗
Sin is not an isolated event

Every sin leaves a stain on the heart. That stain dulls spiritual sensitivity. The dulling makes the next sin easier. It is a chain — silent, progressive, almost invisible.

How the thread with ṣalāh is broken — step by step

① The first sin — the initial breaking point

A sin is committed. The heart still reacts: there is guilt, the call of conscience. The next prayer is difficult — not impossible, but heavy. The heart is stained yet still sensitive.

📖 "The first stain on the heart is like a drop of ink on a white sheet — visible, but cleanable." — Image transmitted from the salaf
② The prayer loses presence — it becomes mechanical

One does not stop praying — one continues, but mechanically. The words are recited without presence of heart. The mind wanders. The sujūd is rushed. The ṣalāh becomes a burden to get over with, not an encounter.

📖 "Prayer without presence of the heart is like a body without a soul." — Ibn al-Qayyim, Al-Wābil al-Ṣayyib
③ The second sin — the threshold lowers

With the heart already dulled, the second sin arrives with less resistance. "It is not that serious." "Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is Forgiving." The logic is correct — but used as an anesthetic instead of a cure.

📖 "The believer sees his sins as a mountain he fears will crush him. The sinner sees them as a fly that passes before his nose." — Bukhārī 6308
④ Prayers begin to be missed

First Fajr is delayed. Then ʿAṣr is missed. Every missed prayer is a void without reset, without spiritual cleansing, without contact with Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ. The heart grows cold.

📖 "The covenant between us and them is the prayer. Whoever abandons it has disbelieved." — Aḥmad 22937 · Nasāʾī 463 (ṣaḥīḥ)
⑤ The rān — the heart closes

Ibn ʿAbbās explained verse 83:14 as the rān: the rust that covers the heart layer upon layer. There is no dramatic moment. There is only a day when one wakes up and feels that Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is distant — without knowing when it happened.

📖 "When the believer commits a sin, a black spot appears on his heart. If he repents, it is polished. If he continues, it spreads until it covers the entire heart." — Tirmidhi 3334 (ḥasan)

⚠ Signs that the chain is underway

→ Prayer feels heavy — you perform it out of obligation, not desire
→ The Qur'an no longer moves you — you hear the words but do not perceive them
→ Sin no longer disturbs you as before — you have "grown used to it"
→ You feel Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ distant — difficulty in du'ā', a sense that it does not reach
→ The company of the heedless feels more comforting than that of the practicing
→ The thought of the ākhirah does not touch you — as if it were abstract or far away

💡 The way out — always available

The chain is not irreversible. Islam has a constant reset mechanism: tawbah. Every sin can be erased. The hardened heart can soften — dhikr, the Qur'an, good company, weeping before Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ are instruments of softening.

قُلْ يَا عِبَادِيَ الَّذِينَ أَسْرَفُوا عَلَى أَنفُسِهِمْ لَا تَقْنَطُوا مِن رَّحْمَةِ اللَّهِ

"Say: O My servants who have transgressed against themselves — do not despair of the mercy of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ."

Qur'an 39:53

🕸
Shayṭān has a precise plan regarding your ṣalāh

He does not ask you to stop praying. He asks you to delay. To rush. To pray distracted. He knows that an empty ṣalāh is almost useless — and an absent ṣalāh is a complete victory.

1
The delay — "you'll pray later"
Not "do not pray" — but "pray in five minutes." Then those five become thirty, then the time passes. Shayṭān knows that systematic delay leads to gradual abandonment.
🛡 Antidote: establish a fixed action at the moment of the adhān — whatever you are doing, you leave it.
2
The waswasa — Khanzab during prayer
Shayṭān — called Khanzab for this function — brings thoughts of work, problems, yesterday's conversations. The prayer becomes an empty shell — formally completed, spiritually absent.
🛡 Antidote: before starting, pause. Breathe. Say A'ūdhu billāh out loud. Blow to the left three times.
3
Normalization — "you are already a good Muslim"
After rushed or missed prayers, Shayṭān normalizes: "You pray when you can, Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ understands." He makes decline appear as a stable plateau, so the need to change is not felt.
🛡 The Prophet ﷺ — already forgiven for everything — wept in prayer until he wet the ground.
4
Despair — "it is too late now"
If you become aware of the decline, he uses the final weapon: "You have lost too much. Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is angry with you." This is the greatest lie of all.
🛡 "If your sins were to reach the sky and you asked Me for forgiveness, I would forgive you." — Tirmidhi 3540
5
Compartmentalization — "prayer and life are separate"
For those who do not abandon prayer: "prayer is prayer, life is life." You pray, but you lie. You pray, but you look at ḥarām. The ṣalāh loses its transformative power.
🛡 Ask after every prayer: "what has changed in me?" The ṣalāh must leave a trace in the hours that follow.
ḥadīth — Khanzab the disturber
إِنَّ الشَّيْطَانَ يَأْتِي أَحَدَكُمْ فِي صَلَاتِهِ فَيَلْبِسُ عَلَيْهِ حَتَّى لَا يَدْرِيَ كَمْ صَلَّى

"Shayṭān comes to one of you during prayer and confuses him to the point that he no longer knows how many rakʿāt he has prayed."

Bukhārī 1232 · Muslim 389

The Prophet ﷺ’s ﷺ remedy: in case of doubt, return to the lesser certain number, then perform two sujūd of correction.

Prayer is light
الصَّلَاةُ نُورٌ

"Prayer is light."

Muslim 223

Not a metaphor — a reality: whoever prays develops a nūr in the face, in perception, in the ability to discern. The ṣaḥāba recognized people by the night prayer visible on their faces.

The first reckoning
إِنَّ أَوَّلَ مَا يُحَاسَبُ بِهِ الْعَبْدُ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ مِنْ عَمَلِهِ صَلَاتُهُ

"The first thing for which the servant will be called to account on the Day of Judgment is the prayer. If it is sound, everything else is facilitated; if it is deficient, everything else is compromised."

Abū Dāwūd 864 · Tirmidhi 413

Ṣalāh is the most accessible and most honest measure of where you stand spiritually.

The covenant between us and them
إِنَّ بَيْنَ الرَّجُلِ وَبَيْنَ الشِّرْكِ وَالْكُفْرِ تَرْكَ الصَّلَاةِ

"Between a man and polytheism and disbelief is the abandonment of prayer."

Muslim 82

A precise boundary. Prayer is not among the good deeds — it is the barrier that separates faith from its abandonment.

Sujūd — the closest moment
أَقْرَبُ مَا يَكُونُ الْعَبْدُ مِنْ رَبِّهِ وَهُوَ سَاجِدٌ فَأَكْثِرُوا الدُّعَاءَ

"The servant is closest to his Lord when he is in prostration — increase in supplication."

Muslim 482

The Islamic paradox: one lowers oneself to draw near. Every sujūd is an opportunity for direct conversation. How long do you remain there?

Sin and the heart — the rān
إِنَّ الْعَبْدَ إِذَا أَذْنَبَ ذَنْبًا نُكِتَتْ فِي قَلْبِهِ نُكْتَةٌ سَوْدَاءُ فَإِنْ تَابَ وَنَزَعَ وَاسْتَغْفَرَ صُقِلَ قَلْبُهُ

"When the servant commits a sin, a black spot appears on his heart. If he repents and seeks forgiveness, his heart is polished. If he continues in sin, the spot expands — until it covers the entire heart."

Tirmidhi 3334 (ḥasan) — Tafsir of Qur'an 83:14

The rān does not arrive suddenly. It is progressive. Ṣalāh and tawbah are the only effective remedies.

The five prayers like a river
أَرَأَيْتُمْ لَوْ أَنَّ نَهَرًا بِبَابِ أَحَدِكُمْ يَغْتَسِلُ فِيهِ كُلَّ يَوْمٍ خَمْسَ مَرَّاتٍ هَلْ يَبْقَى مِنْ دَرَنِهِ شَيْءٌ

"What would you say if there were a river at the door of one of you and he bathed in it five times a day — would any of his dirt remain?" They said: No. He said: "Such are the five prayers."

Bukhārī 528 · Muslim 667

Five spiritual baths each day. Not for the one who is perfect — but for the one who gets dirty and needs washing.

Fajr and ʿIshāʾ — the heaviest for the hypocrites
لَيْسَ صَلَاةٌ أَثْقَلَ عَلَى الْمُنَافِقِينَ مِنْ صَلَاةِ الْعِشَاءِ وَصَلَاةِ الْفَجْرِ

"There is no prayer heavier upon the hypocrites than ʿIshāʾ and Fajr. If they knew what they contain, they would come even crawling."

Bukhārī 657 · Muslim 651

The two moments when the bed is warmest are those of greatest spiritual value. Whoever endures at those times obtains something special.

Prayer is inner light
إِذَا قَامَ أَحَدُكُمْ إِلَى الصَّلَاةِ فَلَا يَبْصُقْ قِبَلَ وَجْهِهِ فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ قِبَلَ وَجْهِهِ

"When one of you stands for prayer — Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is in front of him."

Bukhārī 406 · Muslim 551

When you are in prayer, Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is before you. Not metaphorically. Before you. If we truly felt this, every prayer would be completely different.

Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ descends in the last third of the night
يَنْزِلُ رَبُّنَا تَبَارَكَ وَتَعَالَى كُلَّ لَيْلَةٍ إِلَى السَّمَاءِ الدُّنْيَا حِينَ يَبْقَى ثُلُثُ اللَّيْلِ الْآخِرُ فَيَقُولُ مَنْ يَدْعُونِي فَأَسْتَجِيبَ لَهُ

"Our Lord descends every night in the last third and says: Who calls upon Me that I may answer him? Who asks of Me that I may give? Who seeks My forgiveness that I may forgive?"

Bukhārī 1145 · Muslim 758

Three divine questions every night — three open offers. While the majority sleep, Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ asks: who is there?

Sins fall with every posture
إِنَّ الرَّجُلَ إِذَا قَامَ يُصَلِّي أُتِيَ بِذُنُوبِهِ فَوُضِعَتْ عَلَى رَأْسِهِ وَعَاتِقَيْهِ فَكُلَّمَا رَكَعَ أَوْ سَجَدَ تَسَاقَطَتْ عَنْهُ

"When a man stands to pray, his sins are brought and placed upon his head and shoulders — and every time he bows or prostrates, they fall away from him."

Bayhaqi, Shuʿab al-Imān (ḥasan)

Sins like physical weight on the shoulders — and every rukūʿ and sujūd makes them fall. Every posture of humility is a moment of active purification.

Actions by intention — Niyyah
إِنَّمَا الْأَعْمَالُ بِالنِّيَّاتِ وَإِنَّمَا لِكُلِّ امْرِئٍ مَا نَوَى

"Actions are judged according to intentions. One is rewarded for whatever one intends to do."

Bukhārī, Imān 41 · Muslim, Imāra 155 — Narrator: Umar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb

Imam Aḥmad ibn Ḥanbal said the entire foundations of Islam rest on three ḥadīth, this being one of them. Niyyah is formed in the heart — it does not need to be spoken aloud. It transforms every mundane act into ʿibāda. The same physical action can yield reward, nothing, or sin — based entirely on what the heart intends.

Jibrīl teaches the religion — Iman, Islam, Iḥsān
أَنْ تَعْبُدَ اللَّهَ كَأَنَّكَ تَرَاهُ فَإِنْ لَمْ تَكُنْ تَرَاهُ فَإِنَّهُ يَرَاكَ

"Worship Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ as if you see Him — for if you do not see Him, He certainly sees you." (Definition of Iḥsān from the Ḥadīth of Jibrīl)

Muslim, Imān 1 — Narrator: Umar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb

The Ḥadīth of Jibrīl is called "the mother of the Sunnah" — it teaches the three levels of dīn in one encounter: Islām (outer pillars), Imān (inner belief in Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, angels, books, messengers, Last Day, qadar), and Iḥsān (perfection of worship). Archangel Jibrīl asked as a stranger so the Companions would learn without hesitation. Notice: Islam was asked first (external), then Imān (internal), then Iḥsān (the summit).

Repentance — Tawbah
لَوْ أَخْطَأْتُمْ حَتَّى تَبْلُغَ خَطَايَاكُمُ السَّمَاءَ ثُمَّ اسْتَغْفَرْتُمُ اللَّهَ لَغَفَرَ لَكُمْ

"If your sins reached the sky and you then sought forgiveness from Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, He would forgive you."

Ibn Mājah 4248 (ḥasan) · Tirmidhi 3540

Repentance has three conditions: stopping the sin, remorse, and resolve not to return. A fourth condition applies if the sin harmed another: restoring their right. Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ's forgiveness is not proportional to the sin — it is proportional to His mercy, which is infinite.

Patience — Ṣabr
مَا أُعْطِيَ أَحَدٌ عَطَاءً خَيْرًا وَأَوْسَعَ مِنَ الصَّبْرِ

"No one has ever been given a gift better and more comprehensive than patience."

Bukhārī 1469 · Muslim 1053

Ibn al-Qayyim identified three levels: ṣabr about Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ's commands (obeying them), ṣabr from His prohibitions (abstaining), and ṣabr with His decrees (accepting trials). The ḥadīth says no gift — not wealth, health, or knowledge — surpasses ṣabr because ṣabr is what allows everything else to be used correctly.

Muḥāsaba — Self-accountability
الْكَيِّسُ مَنْ دَانَ نَفْسَهُ وَعَمِلَ لِمَا بَعْدَ الْمَوْتِ

"The intelligent person is the one who holds their soul to account and works for what comes after death."

Tirmidhi 2459 (ḥasan)

True intelligence (kayis) in Islam is not cleverness — it is self-mastery. The believer sits with themselves each night and reviews: what did I intend, what did I do, what did I say? Umar رضي الله عنه said: "Hold yourselves accountable before you are held accountable."

Avoiding Bidʿah — Innovation
مَنْ أَحْدَثَ فِي أَمْرِنَا هَذَا مَا لَيْسَ مِنْهُ فَهُوَ رَدٌّ

"Whoever introduces into this matter of ours that which is not part of it — it is rejected."

Bukhārī, Ṣulḥ 5 · Muslim, Aqḍiyya 17

Bidʿah (innovation) is not about new technology or worldly matters — it is introducing new religious practices with no basis in revelation. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Every bidʿah is misguidance, and every misguidance leads to the Fire." The Sunnah is a complete, perfect path — adding to it implies it was incomplete.

Enjoining good, forbidding evil — Amr biʾl-maʿrūf
مَنْ رَأَى مِنْكُمْ مُنْكَرًا فَلْيُغَيِّرْهُ بِيَدِهِ فَإِنْ لَمْ يَسْتَطِعْ فَبِلِسَانِهِ فَإِنْ لَمْ يَسْتَطِعْ فَبِقَلْبِهِ وَذَلِكَ أَضْعَفُ الْإِيمَانِ

"Whoever among you sees a wrong, let him change it with his hand; if he cannot, then with his tongue; if he cannot, then with his heart — and that is the weakest of faith."

Muslim, Imān 78

The three levels are in descending order of capacity — not permission. The heart-level is called the weakest of faith not because it is sufficient, but because it is the floor below which no Muslim can fall. Silence while approving is not the third level; disapproval from the heart is.

Ties of kinship — Ṣilat al-Raḥm
لَا يَدْخُلُ الْجَنَّةَ قَاطِعٌ

"The one who severs ties of kinship will not enter Paradise."

Bukhārī, Adab 11 · Muslim, Birr 19

Ṣilat al-raḥm is not just visiting — it is maintaining warmth, communication, and care. The ḥadīth scholars note: the one who "maintains" kinship is not the one who reciprocates kindness, but the one who continues even when cut off. As the Prophet ﷺ said: "The one who maintains kinship is not the one who reciprocates — but the one who, when his relatives cut him off, still maintains the tie."

Pride and Humility
لَا يَدْخُلُ الْجَنَّةَ مَنْ كَانَ فِي قَلْبِهِ مِثْقَالُ ذَرَّةٍ مِنْ كِبْرٍ

"No one with even a mustard seed's weight of arrogance in their heart will enter Paradise."

Muslim, Imān 147

A Companion asked: "What if a man loves his clothes to be beautiful?" The Prophet ﷺ replied: "Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is beautiful and loves beauty — kibr (arrogance) is rejecting truth and despising people." Pride is not about appearance — it is about the heart's stance toward truth and toward others. The opposite of kibr is tawāḍuʿ (humility), which the Prophet ﷺ described as raising others' rank, not lowering one's own.

The tongue — control and its weight
مَنْ كَانَ يُؤْمِنُ بِاللَّهِ وَالْيَوْمِ الْآخِرِ فَلْيَقُلْ خَيْرًا أَوْ لِيَصْمُتْ

"Whoever believes in Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ and the Last Day — let them say what is good or remain silent."

Bukhārī, Adab 85 · Muslim, Imān 74

The tongue is the organ that most destroys or builds a person's scale. The Prophet ﷺ warned: "A man may utter a word that pleases Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ without considering it, and Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ elevates him by it. A man may utter a word that displeases Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ without considering it, and it plunges him into the Fire." Two options — good speech or silence. No third option.

Seven under Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ's shade
سَبْعَةٌ يُظِلُّهُمُ اللَّهُ فِي ظِلِّهِ يَوْمَ لَا ظِلَّ إِلَّا ظِلُّهُ

"Seven will be shaded by Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ on the Day when there is no shade but His: a just leader; a youth raised in worship of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ; a person whose heart is attached to the mosque; two who love each other for Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ's sake; a man invited by a woman of beauty and position who says 'I fear Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ'; one who gives charity so secretly the left hand does not know what the right gives; and one who remembers Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ in private and weeps."

Bukhārī 660 · Muslim 1031

The ḥadīth outlines seven categories — notice they cross all areas of life: governance, worship, brotherhood, temptation, charity, and dhikr. Each category has one thing in common: doing the right thing when it is hardest. The youth who worships when desires are strongest; the man who refuses when temptation is at its peak; the giver who hides charity when recognition is available.

🔥
The real war for your ṣalāh

Shayṭān does not ask you to become an atheist. He only asks you to delay, rush, get distracted. He knows that a missed ṣalāh is an open door — and an open door is the beginning of everything else.

⛓
How the chain of sin really works
The psycho-spiritual mechanism explained step by step
①
Sin opens a crack in the heart

Every sin is a nukta sawdāʾ — a black spot — that appears on the heart. The first crack does not destroy. But it creates a space in which the second enters more easily. The heart becomes less sensitive to the distinction between ḥalāl and ḥarām.

📖 "If he repents and seeks forgiveness, the heart is polished. If he continues, the stain spreads until it covers the whole heart — this is the rān." — Tirmidhi 3334
②
The ṣalāh empties — it becomes mechanical

With the crack in the heart, the next prayer feels heavy. One prays, but the words slip away. Ibn al-Qayyim said that prayer without khushūʿ is like a body without a soul. And a prayer without a soul does not create the barrier against the next sin.

③
The next sin arrives with less resistance

Without the protection of a living ṣalāh, the second sin finds the door ajar. The justifications arrive: "It’s not that serious," "Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is Forgiving," "Just once." Truth used as an anesthetic instead of a cure.

⑤
The rān — the heart closes completely

In the end the heart no longer reacts. The Qur'an does not touch it. Sin does not disturb it. There is no obvious breaking point — only one day you wake up and realize something is gone, without knowing when. Even here there is a way out — the hand of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is always extended.

🕸
Shayṭān’s complete plan — 7 levels
From his oath in the Qur'an to the daily trap
قَالَ فَبِمَا أَغۡوَيۡتَنِي لَأَقۡعُدَنَّ لَهُمۡ صِرَٰطَكَ ٱلۡمُسۡتَقِيمَ ۝ ثُمَّ لَآتِيَنَّهُم مِّن بَيۡنِ أَيۡدِيهِمۡ وَمِنۡ خَلۡفِهِمۡ وَعَنۡ أَيۡمَٰنِهِمۡ وَعَن شَمَآئِلِهِمۡ

"I will sit on Your straight path for them. I will attack them from the front, from behind, from the right, and from the left."

Qur'an 7:16-17 — The oath of Iblīs

I
He sits on the straight path — he waits for you at the beginning
He does not attack you in sin — he waits when you want to pray, make tawbah, start again. He sets the obstacle: "you’re not ready," "first get yourself in order," "start tomorrow".
II
Systematic delay
Not "don’t pray." "Pray in five minutes." Those five become twenty, then the time runs out.
"When one of you sleeps and forgets the prayer, Shayṭān urinates in his ear." — Bukhārī 1144
III
Waswasah during the prayer
Khanzab brings work thoughts, worries, yesterday’s memory. He makes you lose count of the rakʿāt. The goal: make the prayer feel like an unbearable burden.
IV
Normalization
After weeks of missed prayers, he normalizes: "You pray when you can, Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ understands." He makes the decline feel like a stable plateau — so you don’t feel the need to change.
V
Compartmentalization
For those who do not abandon prayer: "prayer and life are separate." You pray, but you lie. You pray, but you commit injustice. The ṣalāh loses its transformative power.
VI
Despair
If you wake up and realize the decline: "You left it for months — Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ will no longer accept you." The most dangerous lie of all.
"If your sins reached the sky and you asked Me for forgiveness, I would forgive you." — Tirmidhi 3540
VII
Waiting until the last moment
The final plan: "repent later, when you’re ready, when you’re older." He knows death does not warn.
"Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ accepts repentance until the soul reaches the throat." — Tirmidhi 3537
🕌
What really happens in the prayer
The inner meaning of each posture
🤲 The Niyya — resetting the intention

It is not said out loud. It is formed in the heart. It is the moment you deliberately decide to stand before Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ. The simple act of forming the intention is already a spiritual act.

✋ The Takbīr — Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is greater than all of this

Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰu Akbar — greater than everything occupying your mind: work, anxiety, the phone. Every prayer begins with this declaration of priority. It is not an abstract statement — it is a declaration of war against the nafs.

📖 The Fātiḥa — the dialogue with Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ

In a ḥadīth qudsī, Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ says: "I have divided the prayer into two halves between Me and My servant. When he says: Al-ḥamdu lillāhi — I say: My servant has praised Me." The Fātiḥa is not a recitation — it is a conversation. With every verse you say, Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ responds.

📖 "I have divided the prayer into two halves between Me and My servant." — Muslim 395
🙇 The Rukūʿ — the bowing of greatness

SubḥānAllah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ al-ʿAẓīm: "Glory be to Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, the Most Great." The back is horizontal — you no longer hold your head high. It is the posture of the servant who recognizes Who is before him.

🤲 The Sujūd — the highest point

The lowest physical point is spiritually the highest. Seven parts of the body touch the earth. The Prophet ﷺ said: "The servant is closest to his Lord when he is in sujūd." How long do you stay there?

🕊 The Taslīm — returning transformed

Assalāmu ʿalaykum — peace be upon you. The greeting to the right and left includes the angels who record every deed. Prayer does not close in on itself — it opens toward the world. The one who leaves the ṣalāh should be different from the one who entered it.

🌱
If you pray but your character doesn’t change — where are you?
The question at the center of everything
أَرَأَيۡتَ ٱلَّذِي يُكَذِّبُ بِٱلدِّينِ ۝ فَذَٰلِكَ ٱلَّذِي يَدُعُّ ٱلۡيَتِيمَ ۝ فَوَيۡلٌ لِّلۡمُصَلِّينَ ۝ ٱلَّذِينَ هُمۡ عَن صَلَاتِهِمۡ سَاهُونَ ۝ ٱلَّذِينَ هُمۡ يُرَآءُونَ

"Woe to those who pray but are heedless in their prayer — those who show off to others yet withhold even small acts of help."

Qur'an 107:1-7 — Sūrat al-Māʿūn. Not the one who does not pray — the one who prays with an absent heart.

You can pray five times a day and at the same time: lie, hurt the people closest to you, be arrogant, treat your wife or husband badly, ignore the rights of others. The question is not whether you pray — it is what you bring into the prayer.

Ṣalāh is training in taqwā. Five times a day you stand before Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — the One who sees everything, knows every intention, will judge every deed. Each time with a present heart, that awareness strengthens. Each time mechanically, it atrophies.

يَٰٓأَيُّهَا ٱلنَّاسُ ٱعۡبُدُواْ رَبَّكُمُ … لَعَلَّكُمۡ تَتَّقُونَ

"O people, worship your Lord — so that you may have taqwā."

Qur'an 2:21 — The purpose of ʿibāda is to build taqwā, not replace it.

Character is the fruit of prayer — not something else:

إِنَّ أَكْمَلَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ إِيمَانًا أَحْسَنُهُمْ خُلُقًا

"The believer with the most complete faith is the one with the best character."

Abū Dāwūd 4682 · Tirmidhi 1162 (ṣaḥīḥ)

إِنَّمَا بُعِثْتُ لِأُتَمِّمَ مَكَارِمَ الْأَخْلَاقِ

"I was sent only to perfect the noble qualities of character."

Aḥmad 8952 (ṣaḥīḥ) — The Prophet ﷺ’s mission was character. Ṣalāh is the means. Character is the goal.

مَا مِنْ شَيْءٍ أَثْقَلُ فِي الْمِيزَانِ مِنْ حُسْنِ الْخُلُقِ

"Nothing is heavier on the Scale on the Day of Judgment than good character."

Tirmidhi 2003 (ṣaḥīḥ) — The mīzān weighs character more than anything else.

🪞 6 questions after every prayer:

①
Are you calmer than before?
Ṣalāh is a reset for the nervous system and the heart. If you leave more agitated than when you entered, something did not work.
②
Does the next sin feel heavier to you?
A prayer with presence makes sin harder immediately after. If there is no resistance, the prayer left no shield.
③
Are you kinder to those around you?
The Prophet ﷺ would leave prayer as the best man with his family. Not the most devout in books — the kindest at home.
④
Is your tongue more controlled?
In prayer you recite the Word of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ with the same mouth you speak with. If that mouth an hour later insults or lies — where did the prayer go?
⑤
Do you care about Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ or about how you look?
Prayer done with riyāʾ is one of the signs of Sūrat al-Māʿūn. Before every prayer: who am I doing this for right now?
⑥
Do you remember Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ in the hours that follow?
Prayer should plant the remembrance of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ in the hours between one prayer and the next. If it disappears immediately — it is an island instead of a root.
💌
A direct word — about where you are right now

If you are reading this, there is probably something in your relationship with prayer that weighs on you. Maybe you do it mechanically. Maybe you skip it. Maybe you haven’t prayed in weeks.

It doesn’t matter where you come from. It matters where you want to go.

Shayṭān has built a story around you: that you are too dirty, too far to come back. It is the biggest story he tells. But it is a lie. Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ said: "O My servants who have transgressed against yourselves — do not despair of the mercy of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ. Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ forgives all sins."

All of them. Not most. All.

Prayer is not for those who are already pure. It is for those who want to purify themselves. You don’t have to wait until you are ready. You are ready now.

وَٱلَّذِينَ جَٰهَدُواْ فِينَا لَنَهۡدِيَنَّهُمۡ سُبُلَنَا ۚ وَإِنَّ ٱللَّهَ لَمَعَ ٱلۡمُحۡسِنِينَ

"Those who strive for Us — We will surely guide them to Our ways. Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is with those who do good."

Qur'an 29:69

RIGHTS OF SPOUSES — حُقُوقُ الزَّوْجَيْن

Marriage in Islam: rights, duties and companionship

Islam has given both spouses rights, guaranteeing for them a life of ease, happiness and stability — all founded upon love, truthfulness and sincerity. Choose your perspective.

💍
Marriage in Islam
A covenant of compassion, mercy and love

Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ has commanded marriage in His Book:

فَانكِحُواْ مَا طَابَ لَكُم مِّنَ ٱلنِّسَآءِ مَثْنَىٰ وَثُلَٰثَ وَرُبَعَ فَإِنْ خِفْتُمْ أَلَّا تَعْدِلُواْ فَوَاحِدَةً
"Marry women of your choice, two or three, or four; but if you fear that you shall not be able to deal justly, then only one."
Qur'ān 4:3 — Sūrat al-Nisāʾ

The Prophet ﷺ commanded marriage and addressed the young men saying:

"O young men, whoever among you can afford to get married, let him do so — for it is more effective in lowering the gaze and in guarding one's chastity." Bukhārī 5077 · Muslim 1400

Marriage in Islam is not a contract between two parties that consists merely of affection. It is a covenant which the Muslim embarks upon knowing it requires the harmony of love, serenity, tranquility and happiness for both parties. Our Lord said:

وَمِنْ ءَايَٰتِهِۦٓ أَنْ خَلَقَ لَكُم مِّنْ أَنفُسِكُمْ أَزْوَٰجًا لِّتَسْكُنُوٓاْ إِلَيْهَا وَجَعَلَ بَيْنَكُم مَّوَدَّةً وَرَحْمَةً
"And among His Signs is this, that He created for you wives from among yourselves, that you may find repose in them, and He has put between you affection and mercy."
Qur'ān 30:21 — Sūrat al-Rūm

Marriage contains tranquility for the soul, happiness for the heart, guarding of the chastity, protection of the honour, and a lowering of the gaze. It increases the Ummah of Muḥammad ﷺ and is the reason mankind remains in existence. It spreads love among the family and unites the hearts.

👁
Rights at the Time of Engagement
Looking, truthfulness, and clarifying matters

The man may look at the woman he intends to propose to — not for entertainment, not for examination, not for enjoyment — but with sincere and truthful resolve to propose. This is an important restriction: Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ knows what is inside the heart, and He is the Watcher. The sincerity of the intention is a condition for the looking to be permissible.

From the rights at the time of engagement is truthfulness — explaining matters pertaining to both spouses that need to be clarified before marriage. The Prophet ﷺ said:

"The two parties have the choice so long as they have not separated. If they are honest and open, their transaction will be blessed; but if they tell lies and conceal anything, the blessing of their transaction will be lost." Bukhārī 2079 · Muslim 1532

If the Prophet ﷺ said this about buying and selling with wealth — what then about marriage, which is a continuous relationship?

🥁
Rights at the Time of the Marriage Contract
Announcing the marriage publicly

The Prophet ﷺ distinguished between what is permissible and what is not, and taught the companions how to celebrate the marriage correctly. The Messenger of Allāh ﷺ said:

"The distinction between the impermissible and the permissible is the sound of the Duff." Ibn Mājah 1896

The marital home begins when the two spouses embark upon one boat in the sea of life. Life is a sea of colliding waves — there are winds, delights and sorrows, anger and happiness. The ship requires cooperation from those aboard it. This journey requires both spouses to learn the mutual rights they share.

The Muslim woman draws closer to Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ by fulfilling the rights of her husband — not from the perspective of compensation (if he gives her, she gives him), but based on the word of the Prophet ﷺ: "Your responsibility is upon you, and their responsibility is upon them." (Muslim 1846). She anticipates the reward and a good ending from her Lord.

① Honour and obedience in what is good
The Prophet ﷺ magnified the right of the husband in a vivid way, saying:
"If I were to command anyone to prostrate to anyone other than Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, I would have commanded the woman to prostrate to her husband. The woman has not fulfilled the right of her husband even if he asks her to give herself to him while she is on the back of a camel."
This is not about literal prostration — it is a statement about the magnitude of the right, because Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ has placed upon the husband the responsibility of qiwāmah: guardianship, provision and protection.
② Protecting his wealth
From the rights of the husband upon his wife is that she protects his wealth and does not spend from it except with his permission. The Prophet ﷺ said about the best of women: "She protects him as it relates to her honour and his wealth."
"It is not permissible for a woman to give anything from her husband's wealth except with his permission." Aḥmad 5/267
If he permits her to spend, both are rewarded. The scholars identified three scenarios:
① Specific permission
She receives the full reward and he receives the full reward — neither diminished at all. (Aḥmad 6/99)
② General permission
She receives half of the reward and he receives half of the reward.
③ No permission
The reward goes to the husband for his earning; upon her is the sin — and with Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ refuge is sought.
③ Not fasting voluntarily without his permission
From the rights of the husband is that the wife should not fast an optional (nafl) fast while he is present except with his permission. The Prophet ﷺ said:
"It is not permissible for a woman to fast while her husband is present, except with his permission."
Note: this applies to voluntary fasting only. Obligatory fasting such as Ramaḍān is not subject to this condition.
④ Not admitting into the home those he dislikes
From the rights of the husband is that the wife should not admit into the home those he dislikes. The marital home belongs to both, and its boundaries are maintained through mutual respect and the husband's guardianship (qiwāmah).
⑤ Not going out without his permission
The Prophet ﷺ described the best of women as those who guard themselves and their husband's home in his absence. Obedience within the limits of what is good (maʿrūf) is one of the foundations of a stable and blessed household.
Important: These rights are within the limits of what is good (maʿrūf). There is no obedience to creation in disobedience to the Creator. If the husband commands his wife to do something that Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ has forbidden, she does not obey him in that — and this is the unanimous position of the scholars.

Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ has said: "And due to the wives is similar to what is expected of them, according to what is reasonable." (Qur'ān 2:228). The righteous husband fulfils the rights of his wife seeking the reward of Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — not merely because she fulfils his.

① Financial provision (nafaqah)
It is obligatory upon the husband to provide for his wife — food, clothing and shelter — according to his means and what is customarily reasonable. Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ said: "Let the man of means spend according to his means." (Qur'ān 65:7). This provision is her right regardless of her own wealth. He is obligated even if she is richer than him.
② Affection, kind treatment, and truthful words
From the rights of the wife is that the husband be affectionate towards her with his tongue and his actions. Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ said:
"And live with them in kindness." — Qur'ān 4:19
The Prophet ﷺ even allowed a man to express love for his wife beyond what is strictly felt in the heart — if it brings about happiness and peace in the home. He may compliment her with qualities he hopes she has, express love in exaggerated terms, and say "I will get it for you, inshāʾAllāh" when he is unable to fulfill a request at that moment, rather than causing her distress. This type of speech is not blameworthy if its purpose is peace and joy between the spouses.
③ The husband grooms himself for his wife
The righteous husband grooms himself for his wife — using fragrance, having a good appearance, taking care of himself — just as he wishes and expects for her to do for him. Ibn ʿAbbās رضي الله عنه said:
"Verily, I beautify myself for my wife, just as I love for her to beautify herself for me." — Based on Qur'ān 2:228
④ Sharing in the household duties
From the affection of the husband to his wife is sharing in the household duties with her. This is the Sunnah of the Prophet ﷺ — the Messenger of Allāh ﷺ, the one who received revelation — about whom it was said:
"He used to be in the service of his family, and when the time for prayer came, he would go out to it." Bukhārī
⑤ Consultation and respecting her opinion
Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ said: "And due to the wives is similar to what is expected of them, according to what is reasonable." (Qur'ān 2:228). The scholars said the meaning of "what is reasonable" is what is according to the custom of people.
The man is a good companion to his wife by consulting her, accepting her opinion when she is correct, being good to her family, and seeing good in her based on what is normally accepted. Included in this is consultation between the spouses, respecting each other's opinions, and cooperating upon what will bring about happiness and joy.
⑥ Justice between wives (if more than one)
If a man has more than one wife, Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ made it obligatory upon him to be just between them in what is within his ability — in provision, housing and time. Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ said: "But if you fear that you shall not be able to deal justly, then only one." (Qur'ān 4:3). Complete equality of the heart is beyond human power — but justice in outward treatment and time is required.
⚠
The question of discipline
What the text says and what it does not say

When the Prophet ﷺ initially prohibited men from striking their wives, some women began to disobey. As a result, a permission was given — under very strict conditions. However, when seventy women came to the family of Muḥammad ﷺ in one night, each complaining about her husband, the Prophet ﷺ said:

"These are not the best of you; these are not the best of you." Bukhārī 5363

The scholars unanimously state: hitting — when it is ever permitted — must be without harm, symbolic, and only as a last resort after counsel and separation from the bed. It is not from the character of the best of husbands. The Prophet ﷺ himself never struck a woman.

🏠
A home established upon the religion
The greatest cooperation between spouses

The greatest thing which requires cooperation between the spouses is for the home to be established upon the religion. Both spouses must be concerned with righteousness and assist each other upon it. This brings ease to the mind, contentment to the heart, and the utmost tranquility to the home.

I swear by the One who has my soul in His Hand — nothing brings about tranquility in the home of the spouses greater than the tranquility which is brought about by the spouses cooperating upon the obedience of the Lord of all that exists. The Prophet ﷺ said:

"May Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ have mercy on a man who gets up at night and prays, and he wakes up his wife and she prays, and if she refuses, he sprinkles water in her face. And may Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ have mercy on a woman who gets up at night and prays, and she wakes up her husband and he prays, and if he refuses, she sprinkles water in his face." Abū Dāwūd 1308
🕯
The living house and the dead house
The Prophet ﷺ on remembrance of Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ in the home
"The likeness of a home wherein Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is remembered and the home wherein Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is not remembered is like the living and the dead." Bukhārī 6407

If righteousness is found in the home, happiness will be found in the home. The Prophet ﷺ said:

"From the happiness of man is a righteous wife, a good riding beast, and a spacious home. From the misery of man is an evil home, an evil wife, and an evil riding beast." Ibn Ḥibbān 4033/9
مَنْ عَمِلَ صَٰلِحًا مِّن ذَكَرٍ أَوْ أُنثَىٰ وَهُوَ مُؤْمِنٌ فَلَنُحْيِيَنَّهُۥ حَيَوٰةً طَيِّبَةً
"Whoever does righteousness — whether male or female — while they are a believer, We will surely cause them to live a good life."
Qur'ān 16:97 — Sūrat al-Naḥl

The good life — Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ has taken upon Himself the responsibility to give this to the male and female who do righteous actions, and that is based upon Imān. Cooperate upon righteousness and piety, and do not cooperate upon sin and transgression.

DEVIATION OF THE YOUTH — انحراف الشَّباب

Its causes — and the means to remedy it

The youth are the heart of the society. If the heart is rectified, the entire body is rectified. If it is corrupted, then that will affect the entire society. Based on the lecture of Shaykh Sulaymān al-Ruḥaylī.

The youth are like the heart to the body. If the heart is rectified, the entire body is rectified. If it is corrupted, the entire body will deviate. Hence it is upon us to pay due attention to their cultivation — for they are our future and a reflection of us.
🧭
The meaning of deviation
Going astray from the Straight Path

Deviation means: going astray from the Straight Path — the path of Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ which He ordained for His servants. Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ said:

وَأَنَّ هَٰذَا صِرَٰطِي مُسْتَقِيمًا فَٱتَّبِعُوهُ وَلَا تَتَّبِعُواْ ٱلسُّبُلَ فَتَفَرَّقَ بِكُمْ عَن سَبِيلِهِۦ
"And verily, this is My Straight Path, so follow it, and follow not other paths, for they will separate you away from His Path."
Qur'ān 6:153 — Sūrat al-Anʿām

Deviation has two types:

① Behavioural deviation
Deviation in actions and deeds — caused by desires (shahawāt). The person knows the truth but his desires overpower him.
② Ideological deviation
Deviation in beliefs and creed — caused by doubts (shubuhāt). The person's understanding of the religion is corrupted.

Many of those who deviate do not perceive what they have fallen into. Deviation at its beginning appears as delight — and its end result is great pain in the dunyā and the Hereafter.

📜
Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ sent Muḥammad ﷺ with every good
The Prophet ﷺ warned against all paths of deviation

The Prophet ﷺ described a future in which callers to falsehood would arise from within the Muslim community itself. Ḥudhayfah ibn al-Yamān رضي الله عنه reported that the Prophet ﷺ said:

"There will be callers to the doors of the Hellfire. He who responds to them, they will toss him into it." Ḥudhayfah asked: "O Messenger of Allāh ﷺ, describe them for us." He said: "They will be from our people and speak our language." He said: "So what do you order me to do if I should encounter that?" He said: "Cling to the Jamāʿah of the Muslims and their imām… And if they have no Jamāʿah nor any imām, then withdraw from all of those groups even if you have to bite onto the trunk of a tree until death comes to you while you are in that state." Bukhārī 6673
The causes of deviation are many. These are among the most significant — each one a door through which Shayṭān enters.
Cause 1
Distance from the Jamāʿah and the imām
Shayṭān lies in wait for the children of Adam and devours the lone individual who is distant from the legislative Jamāʿah — just as the wolf devours the lone sheep. He who distances himself from the Jamāʿah of the Muslims abandons uniting with them in their masjid, abandons Ahl al-Sunnah wa-al-Jamāʿah, and makes himself open to deviant ideologies. The callers to falsehood will attack him with their doubts and beautify desires for him. The Prophet ﷺ said:
ḥadīth: "Indeed, the Hand of Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ is with the Jamāʿah." — Tirmidhī 2167, graded ṣaḥīḥ by al-Albānī
Cause 2
Idleness and wasting time
From the reasons for deviation is idleness and not filling one's time with what benefits — neither the dunyā nor the Ākhirah. The Messenger of Allāh ﷺ said: "I hate that I should see a man being idle — neither engaging in anything from work for the dunyā nor work for the Hereafter." (Abū Nuʿaym, Ḥilyat al-Awliyāʾ). Free time — if not filled with good — becomes a door to evil companionship, forbidden entertainment, and gradually: deviation.
ḥadīth: "Take care of five before five: your life before your death, your health before your illness, your free time before your preoccupation, your youth before your old age, and your enrichment before your poverty." — al-Ḥākim 7846, graded ṣaḥīḥ by al-Albānī
Cause 3
Evil and deviant companionship
From the reasons for deviation is evil and deviant companionship. The Arabs say: al-ṣāḥib sāḥib — "the companion drags." A person is on the religion of his close friend, so let each of you look carefully at whom he takes as a close friend. The Prophet ﷺ described this vividly:
ḥadīth: "The example of a good companion and a bad companion is like a perfume seller and a blacksmith. From the perfume seller — either he gifts you, or you buy from him, or at the very least you find a pleasant smell from him. But the blacksmith — either he burns your clothing, or you find a foul smell from him." — Bukhārī 5534 · Muslim 2628
Cause 4
Being deceived by misleading popular phrases
From the reasons for deviation is being deceived by popular phrases that outwardly display mercy but inwardly contain punishment. Examples include:
⚠ "The methodology of tawḥīd"
Applied by callers to takfīr to legitimise their destructive methodology — which has nothing to do with tawḥīd.
⚠ "Salafiyyah"
Applied to the methodology of takfīr — a name used to give a fringe position the legitimacy of the Salaf.
⚠ "Moderate" / "Balanced Islam"
Used to justify abandoning legislated obligations or committing what has been prohibited — framing deviation as wisdom.
⚠ "Splitters of the ummah"
Directed at those who cling to the texts and warn against innovation — to repel people from them and from the Sunnah.

Many fall into behavioural deviation based on desires, or ideological deviation based on doubts, while they do not perceive what they have fallen into. This is a great plot in which the whispers of Shayṭān are supported by the whispers of the people of falsehood.

Principle: We must not be deceived by phrases until we examine their realities and whether they coincide with what Muḥammad ﷺ came with — in light of the understanding of the Salaf of this ummah.
Cause 5
Impulsiveness and hastiness
The deviation of many youth is due to lack of caution, lack of insight into affairs, and lack of contemplation on the end results. Impulsiveness prevents resoluteness and foresight — and causes a person to fall into destruction. The Prophet ﷺ said:
ḥadīth: "Deliberation is from Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, and impulsiveness is from Shayṭān." — Tirmidhī 2012
Our scholars say: Shayṭān incites towards impulsiveness by his whispers — because it prevents the person from thinking, reflecting, and seeking counsel before acting.
For every cause of deviation there is a remedy. The Messenger of Allāh ﷺ did not leave us without guidance — every door Shayṭān opens can be closed.
① Cling to the Jamāʿah and the scholars of the Sunnah
The remedy for distance from the Jamāʿah is to adhere to the advice of the Messenger ﷺ: cling to the Jamāʿah of the Muslims and their imām. You would be amazed at a believer who testifies to Lā ilāha illā Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ — who preserves the pillars of Islām — yet when he hears the advice of other than the Prophet ﷺ, he abandons the Sunnah for the advice of a human being who himself is weighed against what the Prophet ﷺ was upon.
Subject your affairs to the Book of your Lord and the Sunnah of your Prophet ﷺ — not upon your own understanding or the understanding of others like you — but upon the understanding of the Companions and those who accurately transmitted that understanding, with a clear chain, up until this day: the scholars known for the Sunnah and known for knowledge and insight.
② Know the value of time and youth
The youth must know that time is an opportunity, free time is a blessing, and what has passed will never return. We must compel ourselves and direct our youth to utilize free time in what benefits their religion and their dunyā — before that time becomes a calamity upon them.
"Take care of five before five: your life before your death, your health before your illness, your free time before your preoccupation, your youth before your old age, and your enrichment before your poverty." al-Ḥākim 7846 — ṣaḥīḥ
③ Choose righteous companionship
The remedy for evil companionship is choosing righteous companions — those who remind you of Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, who increase you in knowledge, and who support you upon the good. The Prophet ﷺ said: "A person is on the religion of his close friend, so let each of you look carefully at whom he takes as a close friend." (Abū Dāwūd 4833 · Tirmidhī 2378)
④ Examine phrases before accepting them
It is obligatory that we are not deceived by phrases until we examine their realities — and whether they coincide with what Muḥammad ﷺ came with, in light of the understanding of the Salaf of this ummah. When a group applies a beautiful Islamic term to something destructive, investigate: what do they actually mean? What actions does this methodology lead to? Does it match the Qurʾān and the Sunnah upon the understanding of the scholars?
⑤ Cultivate deliberation — abandon hastiness
The youth should be brought up upon deliberation and the abandonment of hastiness until the truth becomes apparent. Know that being deliberate is the path of safety in the dunyā and the Hereafter — and that Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, the Exalted, loves deliberation. Before acting, before sharing, before judging: pause, reflect, consult the people of knowledge.
⑥ Never lose hope in those who have deviated
It is upon us to treat those from among us who have deviated — and to not lose hope regarding anyone. The hearts are between two fingers from the Fingers of al-Raḥmān; He turns them how He wills. Persevere, put reliance upon your Lord, and do not be deluded by yourself — even if you are a caller or one who gives sermons. Review your condition, your speech, and your daʿwah.
🤲
The closing advice
Shaykh Sulaymān al-Ruḥaylī

The reasons for deviation are many. So O noble brothers — it is upon us all to be cognizant of the dangers of deviation, to exert efforts to remedy those reasons, and to treat those among us who have deviated without losing hope in anyone.

It is upon us to persevere and to put reliance upon our Lord, Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, the Mighty and Majestic — whose Wisdom is far-reaching and in whose Hand all affairs lie.

It is upon us to review our condition, our speech and our daʿwah — and to subject them to the Book of our Lord and the Sunnah of our Prophet ﷺ — not upon our own understanding, but upon the understanding of the Companions and those who transmitted it with a clear and accurate chain up until this day.

It is upon the youth to have taqwā of Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ and not to be deceived by the delusional delight which one may find in deviation. For indeed:

Deviation at its beginning is delight — and its end result is great pain in the dunyā and the Hereafter.
🌙
The duʿāʾ of the Shaykh
A supplication for the ummah
O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, guide the stray Muslims. O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, make us rightly-guided guides.
O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, guide us and guide by way of us. O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, make the affairs of uprightness, guidance and taqwā easy for the ummah.
O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, unite the hearts of the Muslims upon guidance and upon the religion.
O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, remove the reasons for separation from the ummah. Give us life with the Sunnah, make us die upon the Sunnah, and resurrect us upon the Sunnah.
O Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, give us love for Your Prophet ﷺ and love for his Sunnah, and make us firm upon it until we meet You, O Lord of all that exists.
📖
ʿIlm al-Ḥadīth — The Science of Ḥadīth
What is ḥadīth, how it was preserved, and how to distinguish authentic from fabricated
📜
Why this matters for every Muslim

The books of Ḥadīth of the first Islamic century constitute the primary sources of religion. Not knowing how to navigate them means not being able to distinguish what the Prophet ﷺ truly said from what was invented, misunderstood, or weakened over time.

📘
The Meaning of "Ḥadīth"
From language to technical term

The Arabic word ḥadīth means "news," "tidings," or "a word." Its plural is aḥādīth. In ancient Arabia, the term was used to express important and esteemed news. Arabs referred to their famous historical days as aḥādīth.

In the Qur'an, the word appears in two senses: as "a special discourse" (at-Tur 52:34) and as "news or tidings" (Ta-Ha 20:9). In the Prophet ﷺ's ﷺ own usage, it referred to his words — and his Companions adopted this usage thereafter.

📖 The study of ḥadīth is called ʿIlm al-Ḥadīth or Uṣūl al-Ḥadīth — the methodology of ḥadīth criticism.
🧩
What counts as ḥadīth?
The scope of the term

The ḥadīth includes:

The Prophet ﷺ's words (qawl)

Sayings attributed to the Messenger ﷺ — the most common form.

The Prophet ﷺ's actions (fiʿl)

What he did — how he prayed, performed ablution, ate, treated his family.

The Prophet ﷺ's approvals (taqrīr)

Things done in his presence that he allowed or did not prohibit.

Companions' words (mawqūf)

Statements of the Ṣaḥāba about the Prophet ﷺ — also recorded as ḥadīth.

🏛
History of ḥadīth collection
How the Sunnah was preserved across centuries
①
The Prophet ﷺ's lifetime

The Companions memorized and wrote down ḥadīth. The Prophet ﷺ initially restricted writing to prevent mixing with the Qur'an, then permitted it for those who could keep them separate.

②
The Caliphs' period

The Rightly Guided Caliphs tightly regulated narration. Abu Bakr and Umar required two witnesses for any ḥadīth. Umar restricted free narration to prevent fabrication after discord appeared.

③
The 2nd–3rd Islamic century

Scholars began compiling systematically. By the third century, approximately one million narrations circulated. Scholars cross-checked narrators one by one, comparing chains and texts.

④
The great compilations

Imam Bukhārī (d. 870 CE) selected 1,563 unique ḥadīth from 600,000 he had collected, producing Al-Jāmiʿ al-Ṣaḥīḥ. Imam Muslim (d. 874 CE) compiled 7,563 from 300,000. Together they form the Ṣaḥīḥayn — the two most authoritative collections.

🌿
The Sunnah — definition and scope
The living model of the Prophet ﷺ

The word Sunnah means "path," "road," or "way." In Islamic scholarship, it refers to everything about the Prophet ﷺ: his words, deliberate and unintentional actions, his character, and his approvals.

The Sunnah is the content — the actual practices and teachings. The ḥadīth are the reported narrations that transmit that content. Sunnah is known today only through ḥadīth.

📖 "Hold fast to my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Rightly Guided Caliphs." — Sunan al-Tirmidhi, ʿIlm 16

The opposite of Sunnah is bidʿah — introducing something into religion with no basis. Those devoted to the Sunnah are Ahl al-Sunnah; those who introduce innovations are Ahl al-Bidʿah.

✨
Ḥadīth Qudsī — the Divine Ḥadīth
Words of Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ narrated by the Prophet ﷺ, outside the Qur'an

Among revelations given to the Prophet ﷺ are words whose meaning came from Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ, but whose wording came through the Prophet ﷺ — not as part of the Qur'an. These are called Ḥadīth Qudsī (Sacred or Divine Ḥadīth).

رَحْمَتِي سَبَقَتْ غَضَبِي

"My mercy prevails over My wrath."

Ḥadīth Qudsī — Bukhārī, Tawḥīd 15

Key distinctions: Ḥadīth Qudsī is not Qur'anic (its wording was not revealed miraculously and cannot be recited in prayer). It is not the Prophet ﷺ's own words (its meaning is attributed to Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ). It occupies a unique category — divine in meaning, prophetic in transmission.

✅
Ṣaḥīḥ — the Sound Ḥadīth
Five conditions that must all be met

A ḥadīth is classified as ṣaḥīḥ (sound/authentic) when it meets five necessary conditions:

①
Righteous narrator (ʿadāla)
Every narrator in the chain must be a Muslim of good moral character — not known for lying, major sins, or religious deviation.
②
Strong memory (ḍabṭ / zabt)
The narrator must have a reliable memory or, if transmitting in writing, careful documentation. Above-average intelligence is sought.
③
Connected chain (ittiṣāl al-sanad)
Every narrator must have actually met the person above them in the chain. A gap makes the ḥadīth defective.
④
Non-anomalous (ʿadam al-shadhdh)
A reliable narrator should not contradict more reliable ones. If they do, the ḥadīth is classified as anomalous (shādhdh).
⑤
No hidden defect (ʿadam al-ʿilla)
There should be no subtle flaw detectable only by experts (muḥaddithīn) — a hidden break in chain, misattribution, or textual error.
📚
Imam Bukhārī and Imam Muslim
The two most authoritative compilations
📕 Imam Bukhārī (d. 870 CE)

Selected 1,563 unique ḥadīth from 600,000 collected. Divided into 97 chapters (kutub) and 3,730 subchapters. Scattered the same ḥadīth under multiple headings to derive different rulings. Considered the most reliable book after the Qur'an — prioritises legal dimension.

📗 Imam Muslim (d. 874 CE)

Selected 7,563 ḥadīth from 300,000. Contains 54 main chapters. Places all narrations of the same ḥadīth together — preserving exact original wording (verbatim transmission). Prioritises ḥadīth methodology.

📖 Ḥadīth agreed upon by both (present in Bukhārī and Muslim) are called muttafaqun ʿalayh — "agreed upon" — and are considered the most reliable of all.
🌸
Ḥasan — the Fair Ḥadīth
Sound in all ways except one narrator's documentation

Defined by Imam Tirmidhi (d. 892 CE). A ḥasan ḥadīth meets all ṣaḥīḥ conditions except that one narrator has a slight weakness in memory — not suspected of lying, but with occasional lapses. The narrator must be:

Renowned in ḥadīth narration
Reliable and righteous in character
Not contradicting more reliable narrators

Both ṣaḥīḥ and ḥasan are maqbūl (acceptable) and can serve as evidence in Islamic law. They are together called maqbūl ḥadīth.

⚠️
Weak Ḥadīth (Ḍaʿīf)
Missing one or more of the five conditions for soundness

A ḥadīth that fails to meet at least one of the five soundness conditions is classified as ḍaʿīf (weak), also referred to as mardūd (rejected) or saqīm (unsound). Some scholars have identified up to 42 distinct types of weak ḥadīth.

Common types by chain defect:

✗
Mursal — the missing Companion
A Tābiʿī narrates directly from the Prophet ﷺ without mentioning the Companion who transmitted it to him. The chain is broken at the most critical link.
✗
Munqaṭiʿ — broken chain
A general term for any chain with a missing narrator (not necessarily a Companion). The break could be anywhere in the middle.
✗
Muʿḍal — double gap
Two or more consecutive narrators are missing from the chain — a more severe break.
✗
Muʿallaq — suspended chain
The author has omitted one or more narrators from the beginning of the chain (closest to him).
✗
Shādhdh — anomalous
A reliable narrator contradicts a more reliable one — in chain or text.
✗
Munkar — denounced
A weak narrator contradicts a reliable one. This is among the weakest types, having two defects simultaneously.
✗
Maqlūb — inverted
A narrator has transposed names in the chain or rearranged words in the text of the ḥadīth.
📏
Rulings on weak ḥadīth
When can they be used — and when must they be avoided?

Not all weak ḥadīth are equal. Scholars grade them from slightly weak to completely abandoned (matrūk). Three conditions allow a weak ḥadīth to be cited:

1
It must not be very weak (i.e., not matrūk or fabricated)
2
It must not contradict the Qur'an or established Sunnah
3
It must be based on a principle already established in sound ḥadīth

Weak ḥadīth have been used in: praise or encouragement of acts already established; warnings against sins already established. They are never used to establish a new legal ruling.

🚫
Fabricated Ḥadīth (Mawḍūʿ)
Invented words falsely attributed to the Prophet ﷺ

The most dangerous category: narrations that were deliberately invented and falsely attributed to the Prophet ﷺ. The Prophet ﷺ warned severely:

مَنْ كَذَبَ عَلَيَّ مُتَعَمِّدًا فَلْيَتَبَوَّأْ مَقْعَدَهُ مِنَ النَّارِ

"Whoever intentionally lies against me, let him prepare his seat in the Fire."

Mutawātir — narrated by 70+ Companions · Bukhārī, ʿIlm 38

Fabricators had various motives: political (supporting a faction), religious (inventing virtues for acts they believed were good), sectarian, or financial. Scholars collected mawḍūʿ ḥadīth in dedicated books precisely to expose them — works like Ibn al-Jawzī's Kitāb al-Mawḍūʿāt.

📖 Abdullah ibn Abbas (d. 687 CE): "Formerly, hearing 'The Messenger said,' people paid heed immediately. But when falsehood appeared and people competed in narration, they would not accept from anyone except those whose character they were assured of." — Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, Muqaddima
⭐
The Ṣaḥāba — Companions of the Prophet ﷺ
Founders of ḥadīth transmission

A Ṣaḥābī is any believer who saw the Prophet ﷺ at least once and died as a Muslim. All Ṣaḥāba are accepted as righteous (ʿudūl) — their character is guaranteed by the Qur'an and Sunnah. This means their narrations do not require investigation of personal character, only chain continuity.

كُنتُمۡ خَيۡرَ أُمَّةٍ أُخۡرِجَتۡ لِلنَّاسِ

"You are the best community ever brought forth for humanity."

Qur'an 3:110

Key categories of Ṣaḥāba: the Emigrants (Muhājirūn) from Mecca; the Helpers (Anṣār) from Medina; those promised Paradise (ʿAshara al-Mubashshara). The most prolific narrators include: Abu Hurayra (5,374 ḥadīth), Ibn ʿUmar, ʿĀʾisha, Anas ibn Mālik, Ibn ʿAbbas.

🌱
The Tābiʿūn — Successors
The generation after the Companions

The Tābiʿī (pl. Tābiʿūn) is a person who met one of the Companions and died as a Muslim. The greatest Muslim scholars lived in this generation. The "Seven Jurists of Medina" (Fuqahāʾ al-Madīna al-Sabʿa) were all Tābiʿūn:

Saʿīd ibn al-Musayyib
d. 723 CE
Qāsim ibn Muḥammad
d. 723 CE
ʿUrwa ibn Zubayr
d. 713 CE
Khārija ibn Zayd
d. 718 CE
Abu Salama ibn ʿAbd al-Raḥmān
d. 722 CE
ʿUbayd Allāh سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ ibn ʿUtba
d. 717 CE
Sulaymān ibn Yasār
d. 722 CE

Tābiʿūn scholars established the Islamic disciplines on strong intellectual grounds, with deep command of both transmission (riwāya) and critical understanding (dirāya).

🔍
How to verify a ḥadīth today
A practical guide for every Muslim
①
Check if it is in Bukhārī or Muslim
If a ḥadīth appears in both Bukhārī and Muslim, it is muttafaqun ʿalayh — the highest grade of authenticity. You can search on sunnah.com with any key phrase.
②
Look for a graded reference
A well-cited ḥadīth includes: source (e.g., Muslim), chapter name, and ḥadīth number. "Ṣaḥīḥ" or "Ḥasan" grading by scholars like al-Albānī or ibn Ḥajr is a positive sign.
③
Be suspicious of no-source ḥadīth
If someone says "the Prophet ﷺ said..." with no source, no chain, or only a vague reference — treat it with caution. This was precisely the criterion the early Companions used: they would not accept narrations from unverified sources.
④
Common red flags for fabricated ḥadīth
Extreme rewards for minor acts · Bizarre subject matter contradicting Qur'an · Grammatical errors in Arabic text · Content praising a specific person, city, or political group · No known source in the classical ḥadīth books
⑤
What to do if you cannot verify
The Prophet ﷺ said: "It is sufficient lying for a man to repeat everything he hears." (Muslim, Muqaddima 3). If you cannot verify — do not share. If you already shared something that turned out to be fabricated — correct it openly.
📋
Quick reference: grades of ḥadīth
From most to least reliable
Mutawātir
Narrated by so many Companions independently that fabrication is impossible. The highest certainty.
Ṣaḥīḥ
All 5 conditions fully met. Legally binding. Bukhārī and Muslim contain the most rigorously verified ṣaḥīḥ ḥadīth.
Ḥasan
Slight weakness in one narrator's memory only. Acceptable — used as evidence. Present in Tirmidhi and Abu Dawud.
Ḍaʿīf
Missing one or more conditions. Not used for legal rulings. May be cited for encouragement if not very weak.
Matrūk
Narrator accused of lying or extremely unreliable. Completely abandoned — not cited under any circumstances.
Mawḍūʿ
Fabricated — deliberately invented. Attributing it to the Prophet ﷺ is a major sin. Must be exposed and warned against.
🕊
A word about sharing ḥadīth today

In the age of social media, fabricated and weak ḥadīth spread faster than authenticated ones — because they are often more dramatic, more comforting, or more politically useful. The early scholars said: "This knowledge is religion — so be careful from whom you take your religion."

The bar is not perfection. You do not need to be a ḥadīth scholar. The bar is care: before you share a saying of the Prophet ﷺ, spend 30 seconds checking if it appears in a classical source. That act of verification is itself an act of respect for the Messenger ﷺ.

The Prophet ﷺ warned that lying against him leads to the Fire. He also said that repeating something unverified is itself a lie. These are not harsh words — they are protection. They protect the Sunnah, they protect you, and they protect everyone who reads what you share.

RAMADAN — رَمَضَان

The month of the Qur'an

Ramadan is not a diet. It is the month in which the Qur'an descended, the gates of Paradise are opened, and Shayṭān is chained. Here you find its meaning, its acts of worship, its nights — and what Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ promises those who live it with taqwā.

شَهۡرُ رَمَضَانَ ٱلَّذِيٓ أُنزِلَ فِيهِ ٱلۡقُرۡءَانُ هُدٗى لِّلنَّاسِ

"The month of Ramadan in which the Qur'an was revealed — a guidance for mankind."

Qur'an 2:185 — Sūrat al-Baqarah

📖

The month of the Qur'an

The Qur'an descended in Ramadan. The Prophet ﷺ would review the entire Qur'an with Jibrīl every Ramadan — twice in his final year. Every recitation in this month carries a weight beyond ordinary days.

🚪

Gates of Paradise opened

"When Ramadan enters, the gates of Paradise are opened, the gates of Hellfire are closed, and the devils are chained." (Bukhārī 1899) The path is cleared. The environment itself changes.

🛡

Fasting as a shield

"Fasting is a shield." (Bukhārī 1894) — The Arabic word junnah means a protective barrier. Ramadan is not deprivation; it is armour against what weakens the soul and draws it to sin.

🌿

Taqwā — the purpose

"So that you may attain taqwā." (Qur'an 2:183) — The goal of fasting is not hunger. It is God-consciousness: that the servant feels Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ watching in every moment, in public and in private.

🌅 The three ten-day periods

1–10
First ten — Raḥma (Mercy): The month opens with Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ's mercy. Multiply du'ā, recitation, and good deeds. These days set the tone for everything that follows.
11–20
Second ten — Maghfira (Forgiveness): Intensify istighfār. Every sin, every regret — bring it before Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ. His forgiveness in Ramadan is wider than any other time.
21–30
Final ten — ʿItq min al-Nār (Freedom from the Fire): The most precious nights of the year. The Prophet ﷺ would tighten his belt, stay up all night, and wake his family. Laylat al-Qadr is hidden among these nights.
يَـٰٓأَيُّهَا ٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُواْ كُتِبَ عَلَيۡكُمُ ٱلصِّيَامُ كَمَا كُتِبَ عَلَى ٱلَّذِينَ مِن قَبۡلِكُمۡ لَعَلَّكُمۡ تَتَّقُونَ

"O you who believe, fasting has been prescribed for you as it was prescribed for those before you — so that you may attain taqwā."

Qur'an 2:183 — Sūrat al-Baqarah

🤲
Du'ā at the time of breaking fast
One of three whose du'ā is never rejected
ذَهَبَ الظَّمَأُ وَابْتَلَّتِ الْعُرُوقُ وَثَبَتَ الأَجْرُ إِنْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ

"The thirst is gone, the veins are moistened, and the reward is confirmed — if Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ wills."

Abū Dāwūd 2357 — ḥasan

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Three people's du'ā is not rejected: the fasting person at iftar, the just ruler, and the oppressed person." (Tirmidhi 3598) — Do not waste the moment of iftar on food before du'ā.

🌙
Tarāwīḥ — the night prayer of Ramadan
Whoever prays it with faith and hope, all past sins are forgiven
مَنْ قَامَ رَمَضَانَ إِيمَانًا وَاحْتِسَابًا غُفِرَ لَهُ مَا تَقَدَّمَ مِنْ ذَنْبِهِ

"Whoever stands in prayer during Ramadan with faith and seeking reward — all his past sins are forgiven."

Bukhārī 2009, Muslim 759

Two conditions: īmānan (genuine faith) and iḥtisāban (for Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ alone, not social expectation). Both must be present to unlock the full forgiveness.

🍽
Suḥūr — the pre-dawn meal
Sunnah and barakah, not just food
تَسَحَّرُوا فَإِنَّ فِي السَّحُورِ بَرَكَةً

"Take suḥūr, for in suḥūr there is barakah."

Bukhārī 1923, Muslim 1095

Even a sip of water at suḥūr carries reward. The Prophet ﷺ said the difference between our fast and the fast of the People of the Book is this meal. It is an act of worship, not just nutrition.

💰
Ṣadaqah — charity in Ramadan
The Prophet ﷺ was more generous than the blowing wind

Ibn ʿAbbās: "The Prophet ﷺ was the most generous of people, and he was most generous in Ramadan when Jibrīl met him. He was then more generous than the blowing wind." (Bukhārī 6) Every good deed is multiplied in Ramadan.

🏕
Iʿtikāf — spiritual seclusion
The Sunnah of the final ten nights

The Prophet ﷺ observed iʿtikāf in the final ten nights of Ramadan every year until his death. (Bukhārī 2026) In his final year, he observed it for twenty nights. Remaining in the mosque — cutting off from worldly concerns to focus entirely on Allah سُبْحَانَهُ وَتَعَالَىٰ and the ākhirah.

لَيۡلَةُ ٱلۡقَدۡرِ خَيۡرٞ مِّنۡ أَلۡفِ شَهۡرٍ

"The Night of Decree is better than a thousand months."

Qur'an 97:3 — Sūrat al-Qadr

✨ What is Laylat al-Qadr?
